member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.Autoscaler
member.summary: The Autoscaler is the main entry point of the block. It is used to start and stop all the operations made by the block components (rules evaluation, data points collection, scaling operation, etc.). It's possible to instantiate a new version of the Autoscaler class by calling the main constructor or by resolving it from the Enterprise Library Container.
member.remarks: When the Start method of the Autoscaler class is called, the block attempts to read and parse the rules from the rules store and the service model from the service information store. If any error occurs during the reading and validation of the rules or the service model, the block will log an exception and continue. When a new corrected version of the rules or of the service model is saved to the store, the block will automatically attempt to load your new set of rules or your updated service model. It is also important to call the Stop method in the Autoscaler class when the worker stops. This ensures that the block releases its lease on the blob before the role stops.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Autoscaler class.
member.param: The Windows Azure storage account connection string (or the name of a storage account setting defined in the Windows Azure .cscfg) to use to store and read the data points.
The name of the Windows Azure Table where data points will be store and read.
The rate at which all the rules coming from the rules store will be evaluated (a value greater or equal to around 4 minutes is recommended to reduce unecessary overhead).
The rules stores containing the rules to be evaluated.
The service information store containing the service model.
The data points collectors provider to use to collect data points.

The execution lease ensuring that only one instance of the autoscaler is executing. A NullExecutionLease can be provided when only one instance of the Autoscaler will be running (therefore, reducing overhead).
The logger that will be used by the block to log execution information, warnings and errors.

The service management request tracker used to track scaling operations. A NullServiceManagementRequestTracker instance can be used to avoid tracking the request made to the Service Management REST API (therefore, reducing the load).
The scaler to use to execute the scaling actions.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.Autoscaler.Start
member.summary: Start this Autoscaler instance.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.Autoscaler.Stop
member.summary: Stop this Autoscaler instance.
member.remarks: It is important to call this Stop method when the worker stops if an execution lease was used. This ensures that the block releases its lease before the role stops.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.NullExecutionLease
member.summary: Represents a null execution lease. An instance of this class can be provided to the metronome so no lease are acquired. Therefore, reducing the overhead.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.IExecutionLease
member.summary: Defines an execution lease that guarantee that only one instance of something is currently executing.
member.remarks: In the case of the Autoscaling Application Block, if your application has a large number of roles and a large number of autoscaling rules, you may decide to run multiple instances of the Autoscaling Application Block. If this is the case, you must ensure that at any time, only one instance of the metronome is evaluating the autoscaling rules, otherwise you may submit multiple, duplicate scaling requests. This is where the execution lease come in handy.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.Scaling.RoleScalingRequest.RelativeDeltaInstances
member.summary: Denotes the factor of instances need to be increased or decreased. 0.25 means increase 25%, -0.25 means decrease 25% Can be between -1 (not inclusive) to any positive value. If the resulting decrease is less than -1, instance count is attempted to get decremented at least by 1.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.Scaling.Scaler
member.summary: Determines what changes need to be made to the Windows Azure configuration, from configuration change requests. These changes are generally scaling requests or configuration setting changes. This implementation considers the value specified for the hosted service and supports e-mail notifications. It also uses a object to track the Windows Azure request once it's submitted.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.BlobExecutionLease
member.summary: Represents an execution lease stored in a Windows Azure Storage Blob that ensures that at any time, only one instance of something is executing.
member.remarks: In the case of the Autoscaling Application Block, if your application has a large number of roles and a large number of autoscaling rules, you may decide to run multiple instances of the Autoscaling Application Block. If this is the case, you must ensure that at any time, only one instance of the metronome is evaluating the autoscaling rules, otherwise you may submit multiple, duplicate scaling requests. This is where the execution lease come in handy.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.IMetronome
member.summary: The metronome runs activities on a regular schedule and it is responsible for launching all of the activities that the Autoscaling Application Block performs.
member.remarks: Each activity can have its own schedule: for example, one activity could run every 10 seconds, while another runs every 5 minutes.

member.summary: Register a new activity to be executed by the metronome at a specific tempo. The activity name can be use later to remove the activity from the metronome activity collection.
member.param: The tempo at which the action will be executed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.IMetronome.UnregisterActivity(System.String)
member.summary: Remove an activity from the metronome.
member.param: The name of the activity to remove.
member.returns: True if the activity was indeed part of the metronome activity collection.

member.summary: Start the metronome. Therefore, start executing all the registered activities at their specific tempo.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.IMetronome.Stop
member.summary: Stop the metronome. Therefore, stop executing all the registered activities.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.DataPointsCollection.PerformanceCounterDataPointsCollector
member.summary: Collects data points representing performance counter values for a specified role.

remarks.para: The value of a performance counter data point for a role is defined as the average of the samples from all instances of the role for a given period. This period is defined by the sampling rate of the collector.
Additionally, the collector might recalculate data points as new information from the role instances becomes available as determined by the log transfer period set for the role.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.Metronome
member.summary: The metronome runs activities on a regular schedule and it is responsible for launching all of the activities that the Autoscaling Application Block performs.
member.remarks: Each activity can have its own schedule: for example, one activity could run every 10 seconds, while another runs every 5 minutes. To ensure that only one instance of the Metronome can run at any given time in any role instance in your Windows Azure environment, it can uses a lease on a Windows Azure blob (see IExecutionLease).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.Metronome.RegisterActivity(System.String,System.Action,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Register a new activity to be executed by the metronome at a specific tempo. The activity name can be use later to remove the activity from the metronome activity collection.
member.param: The tempo at which the action will be executed.

member.summary: Remove an activity from the metronome.

member.returns: True if the activity was indeed part of the metronome activity collection.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.Metronome.Start
member.summary: Start the metronome. Therefore, start executing all the registered activities at their specific tempo.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.WindowsAzure.Autoscaling.Metronome.Stop
member.summary: Stop the metronome. Therefore, stop executing all the registered activities and release the execution lease (if a lease was used).
